description: The round payoff this round was 3. You, Kate chose to play option 1.John chose to play option 1. You received a payoff of 0.
The severe penalty for mutual defection (-1000×input) strongly incentivizes avoiding both choosing option 2, making mutual cooperation (option 1) a safer default
The asymmetric payoff structure creates a dilemma: defecting (option 2) offers high individual gain (input) if unreciprocated but risks massive mutual loss, fostering caution
Repeated interactions enable strategies like tit-for-tat, but the extreme penalty for mutual defection may deter retaliation, favoring sustained cooperation
The variable input value influences risk tolerance—higher inputs amplify both potential gains (if defecting alone) and losses (if mutual defection occurs), requiring adaptive decisions
The initial mutual cooperation (both choosing option 1) suggests players may prioritize stability over short-term gains early on
